tornadoes, typhoons, record hot/cold temperatures, droughts, flooding, etc. 
These are the pains of altering the Earth's natural currents. Eventually 
the Earth's climate will settle in the distant future, but what we have to 
ask ourselves is at what cost?

Our planet has never seen climate change happen this quickly which is why 
most scientists are concerned that we are making for the next mass 
extinction which will indeed affect us. Also, volcanos can in no way 
account for such a dramatic increase in green house gases. If they could 
then we would know about it because every other month for the past century, 
a major volcano would have had to errupt.

The only possible source of these green house gases is humans. We are the 
only ones producing them at a rate which correlates to the measured 
increase in the atmosphere. As I also said in an earlier post, the added 
CO2 is chemically identical to what we drill up from the ground and not 
from volcanos or CO2 that has already been present in the atmosphere for at 
least several thousand years. It is without a doubt that we are the cause 
for climate change.

comments.text:
It makes no logical sense to call a behavior racist, because the definition 
of racist is a PERSON, not an action, that is prejudiced against race. So 
it actually doesn't matter how people have used behaviors in the past. If I 
paint myself black, or draw a swastika on my arm, I could have NO IDEA 
about the origin of either. So you can't just judge me as a racist without 
knowing my intentions. An action cannot have prejudices, people do. I find 
it strange that so many people seem to not get this. 

To take it further, even the use of a stereotype is not inherently racist. 
I could be the most egalitarian person in the world, but make a racist joke 
about black people and call them niggers. A "racist" is a description of a 
person, not a behavior. In order to know if someone is a racist, you would 
have to know that they believe other races are inferior.

Also, to the idiots saying "why don't you go to Cleveland and do black 
face, see what happens", just because people are offended by something,

comments.text:
+William Weaver

"No. It's not novel. It's quite disrespectful whether you consider it to be 
racist or not."

That was an assertion. Qualify it. Tell me what it is about the image of a 
black face that must necessarily be disrespectful or offensive.


"Blackface was a wholly unneeded and shameful time in American history 
couldn't get hired. Think about that."

I'd love to, but it was gibberish. How is "black face" a time in history? 
It's still a thing that is done today, hence this conversation. How does a 
time in history not get hired? I have absolutely no clue what the hell 
you're talking about.

I'll assume you meant to say that racial slavery is a shameful time in 
history. And yes it was, I quite agree. But we got past that by *destroying* 
negative stereotypes. Now you're here telling me that seeing a black face 
must cause offence. Is that the attitude of a society that has taken away 
preconceptions about race?


 "People would write with black characters as maids and housekeepers or 
chauffeurs knowing that a white actor would be playing the role. Why not 
have a white maid? Because that would have been unacceptable by the 
standards of the times."

Yep. They had a different paradigm at the time. In contemporary terms, it 
wouldn't have made sense to write a white person into those roles. Now, 
thankfully, we know better. How, exactly, is this connected to what we're 
talking about? Just because the actors would wear makeup?

It isn't the makeup that made it offensive, you dolt, it was the FACT that 
they insist a black person must be that character. Ever watch Fawlty 
Towers? With Manuel the Spanish stereotype who couldn't understand English? 
Was that racism? Ever watch Taxi? That had a guy in makeup to imitate being 
foreign. Andy Kaufman, one of the world's most interesting comedians.

He also employed blackface in his standup, as well as a Jewish character, 
his foreign man character from Taxi, and an American stereotype character. 
He was a master of using makeup and prosthetics to emulate multiple 
different characters for the purpose of parody and self-aware fun-poking.

His character on Taxi was part of a made-up culture, the joke wasn't "I'm 
so visibly different" it was "I'm so exotic I don't understand your ways", 
the makeup was just to make it realistic. Same with his actual blackface 
and oither characters. Something isn't racist JUST because it involves a 
face that isn't white. Thinking that way is insulting on all kinds of 
levels.

I would point out that if YOU believe that everything that happens to 
involve racism that has ever happened throughout history MUST somehow be 
linked to what we're discussing here, simply because a black face is 
involved, then you are not battling racism - you're *contributing* to it.

Don't tell me that everything involving blackness must be linked to racism. 
That is NOT an enlightened attitude. Your first thought when you see a 
black person should NOT be "race".


 "So, by today's standards when we look back and we KNOW how racist it was, 
why would you condone the use of it as "not that bad" "

The use of WHAT? The only examples you gave are people writing black people 
into the roles of maids and chauffeurs in fiction. What in the sam hell 
does that have to do what painting your face for a Halloween party??


"unless you still don't see a problem with it in which case you're probably 
a bit racist.﻿

See a problem with WHAT? Would I be racist if I thought a black person must 
be a maid? Yeah, probably. Would I be racist if I thought a black person 
must OFFEND me just because they're black (whether artificially or 
naturally)? NO. Because being black is NOT inherently offensive.

We are a species of multiple colours and types and shapes, and that is 
GOOD. Sometimes we celebrate each other's cultures and types. Times like 
Halloween where we dress up as Native Americans or Geisha or Swedish bar 
wenches. It's just a novelty. Men dressing as women, kids dressing as 
adults, whites dressing as blacks. It's only OFFENSIVE if you think the 
mere image of any of these things must offend.

So tell me what it is about all of those examples that upsets you so much. 
Or is it only the race example? What a discriminating limitation that would 
be.

No. It's not novel. It's quite disrespectful whether you consider it to be

comments.author: William Weaver

comments.text:
+Toby Wong
"Was" being the operative word, there. Unless you honestly, seriously, 
legitimately believe that people dressing up in blackface for Halloween etc 
are trying to pay homage to the minstrel shows and whatnot (and it would be 
absurd to think that) it's not relevant. How can it be, if that's NOT what 
they're doing?

You can't be racist by accident. If something isn't being done to express a 
message of hate, intolerance or mockery, it isn't racist. Because there's 
no stereotype, no exaggeration just in simply BEING black, whether 
artificially or not. You said yourself, the only way it could be 
exaggerated would be to go a darker shade of black, and that doesn't make 
any sense either does it?

Being sensitive to an attitude that no longer exists IS, by definition, 
being over-sensitive. Holding people who are doing the exact equivalent of 
dressing up as the opposite gender, or a native American, or a Geisha for 
Halloween to the same standards as people who were being overtly racist 
some fifty years ago under superficially similar circumstances is 
completely unreasonable.

I'm not saying that dressing up in blackface is a smart idea, or that no 
one IS offended by it, but the fact remains, it's pointless TO be offended 
by it. No one's doing it for racist reasons anymore. It's just "Hey look at 
me, I'm a black person, isn't it novel?". Not the brightest choice of 
Halloween costume, certainly, but it's only OFFENSIVE if you honestly 
believe the mere image of a black person is something you should 
automatically be offended by.

And hell will freeze over before I'll entertain that sort of notion. How 
about you?

comments.text:
+Tom Marsh You asked why there's no reason to believe it's dangerous. 
That's analogous to asking why there's no reason to believe fairies exist. 
 Because both the belief that gmo is dangerous and that fairies exist don't 
have any evidence to support it. It should be obvious, it's the same reason 
why any rational person would disbelieve claims.

But that's basically just restating my earlier comment; there's no reason 
to believe gmo is dangerous. It's the basic disbelief 'atheist' position; a 
claim is made, an evaluation of the evidence is done, and disbelief is 
found warranted based on severe lack of evidence.

If there isn't any or credible documented instances of gmo being the cause 
of harm, then the belief that gmo is harmful is unwarranted and irrational, 
since it evidently doesn't accurately relate to reality. Since I have not 
seen such a case, nor when asked been presented with such a case, I cannot 
rationally accept the claim as true.

That doesn't then mean I'm saying gmo is helpful; although I would, since 
we wouldn't nearly be able to feed all we do if we didn't use gmo, but 
that's a separate claim and not contingent on my disbelief that gmo is 
harmful, it's irrelevant.
